sense.name: cover something, put something over something else
sense.examples: The mountain was capped with snow. Snow capped the mountain. You should have your teeth capped. Cap the pipes if they start to leak.

sense.name: limit or restrict the number or amount of something
sense.examples: How can you cap someone for how little they earn? They need to cap cost-of-living increases. Should the cost of prescription drugs be capped?

sense.name: surpass or improve on a previous action or product
sense.examples: He capped his last trick with a disappearing act that brought the audience to its feet. The graceless Duke of Queensberry capped his previous infamy by cutting down all his wood. This year's qualification caps the best season in UTD Debate history.

sense.name: complete or add a finishing touch to a process or an effort
sense.examples: We capped the meal with dessert. He capped off the meeting with a radical proposal. We capped off the celebration with a bottle of champagne. He capped his record-breaking season as the youngest entry in the US Olympic Trials
